channel.title: University of South Florida on Kramer Ecology Lab
channel.description: Recent content in University of South Florida on Kramer Ecology Lab

item.title: Welcome to our New Undergraduate Student
item.description: Alexander is dual majoring in mathematics and microbiology, with a minor in Russian. In general, he is interested in disease ecology and how it relates to epidemiology. In the lab, Alexander will begin assisting our Masters student, Travis Flock, in conducting a meta-analysis on trait-mediated interactions. We are happy to have Alexander join our team and excited to see how his interests will contribute to our lab!

item.title: Graduate student opening (Ph.D./M.S.) - Population and Community Ecology
item.description: The Kramer laboratory in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of South Florida is seeking motivated graduate students (Ph.D. or M.S.) to study the dynamics of extinction, species invasions, and/or species coexistence. The lab uses a combination of laboratory and field experiments, quantitative models, and computational analysis of big datasets to address basic and applied questions about population dynamics and persistence. Potential study systems range from zooplankton to microbes to emerging wildlife diseases.

item.title: Graduate student opening (Ph.D./M.S.) - Spatial ecology of invasive species
item.description: The Kramer laboratory in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of South Florida is seeking a graduate student to study the spatial dynamics of invasive species using computational approaches, including machine learning and species distribution models. Research in the lab includes the population ecology of invasion, extinction and species coexistence. This project will build on previous work on forecasting potential invaders and patterns of spatial spread. Applicants interested in species distribution models, spatial dynamics, or aquatic invasive species are particularly encouraged to apply.

item.title: Welcoming our New Lab Members
item.description: We are pleased to welcome to our team graduate students, Fargam Neinavaie and Travis Flock, and Lindsey Mixer as our lab technician/manager. Fargam is working on her Ph.D to develop a project on forecasting invasive species. Travis is working on his Masters using meta-analysis to examine the costs of trait-mediated interactions. Lindsey is helping to set up our new lab at the University of South Florida and will be managing day to day tasks.

item.title: Zooplankton Diversity Project website
item.description: I have contributed substantially to the development of this website (http://zooplankton.ecology.uga.edu) from the Drake Laboratory of Population Dynamics at the University of Georgia that provides interested researchers and educators with access to our publicly available dataset. The variety and abundance of data is communicated via interactive visualizations custom developed in Javascript. It includes 17,596 lines of open data on 485,047 zooplankton specimens representing 133 taxa collected from Carolina Bays of the Savannah River Site.

item.title: Allee effects Special Feature at Journal of Animal Ecology
item.description: See the editorial (Kramer, Berec and Drake 2018, http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1365-2656.12777/fullScience) and the full issue (http://besjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/hub/issue/10.1111/jane.2018.87.issue-1/)

item.title: New article featured at Journal of Animal Ecology
item.description: Journal of Animal Ecology has published a commentary (Kuparinen 2018 http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1365-2656.12774/full), on our article, Density-dependent selection on mate search and evolution of Allee effects (Berec, Kramer and Drake 2018, http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1365-2656.12662/full).

item.title: Recruiting Master's student in population ecology of invasive species
item.description: MSc opportunity - Population ecology of invasive species The Kramer laboratory in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of South Florida is seeking a graduate student to study the spatial dynamics of invasive species using computational approaches, beginning in August 2018. Research in the lab includes the population ecology of invasion, extinction and species coexistence. This project will build on previous work on forecasting potential invaders and patterns of spatial spread.

item.title: Recruiting students in population and community ecology
item.description: Graduate student openings (Ph.D./M.S.) in Population and Community Ecology The Kramer laboratory in the Department of Integrative Biology at the University of South Florida is seeking motivated graduate students (Ph.D. or M.S.) to study the dynamics of extinction, species invasions, and/or species coexistence. The lab uses a combination of laboratory and field experiments, quantitative models, and computational analysis of big datasets to address basic and applied questions about population dynamics and persistence.

item.title: Moving to the University of South Florida
item.description: I am starting a quantitative and aquatic ecology laboratory at the University of South Florida. I will be recruiting staff and graduate students, look for announcements here.
